body: @wynot12 I actually prefer the way that you have suggested as an option. I think the test code would be best if they are in its corresponding sub-modules.

It looks that this code has more complex dependencies than I thought.

Decomposing compiler-tests into sub-modules accompanies following cyclic dependencies:
- `compiler-backend -> compiler-optimizer -> compiler-common -> nemo-client -> nemo-driver -> compiler-backend`
- `compiler-optimizer -> compiler-common -> nemo-client -> nemo-driver -> compiler-optimizer`

As I think, the current PR is the best effort without modifying the actual test codes.
@wonook I'll close this PR and make a new PR for handling multiple issues (2, 106, 117)  at once.

Here's the Nemo-internal dependency diagram after this PR.
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1S5EIFBDT7INfCTwRAW3ZcxrlGxVdDuvfTnyu1LRiFQ0/edit?usp=sharing
Is it necessary to keep the `plangenerator` and `runtime/test` packages separate?

Also, can the other compiler packages simply depend on the `compiler/test` package, and the tests be distributed in appropriate packages instead of in the `compiler/test` package?
The same applies for the `runtime/test` package.
@johnyangk Please check the updates. Thanks.
Thanks @seojangho I've addressed your comment.

@wonook Thanks for review and suggestion!

First, I didn't know `plangenerator` module is also for tests, since it's name is confusing.
And they cannot be a single module due to cyclic dependency (runtime-test -> runtime-master -> runtime-plangenerator).

Second, I'd also love to separate tests more clean as you pointed out, but several tests have complex dependencies as I described in the PR description.
Especially, `nemo.compiler.optimizer.pass.compiletime` tests cannot go to corresponding module (nemo-compiler-optimizer).
It's because those tests use `JobLauncher` in `nemo-client` package. `nemo-client` has dependency on `nemo-compiler-optimizer` module again, which means cyclic dependency.

Please refer https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1S5EIFBDT7INfCTwRAW3ZcxrlGxVdDuvfTnyu1LRiFQ0/edit?usp=sharing
I'll resolve conflicts soon.

I know that the package dependency of PR is not clear, but it's because of the design of existing tests.
I believe this PR is better than before.

@johnyangk Thank you for the comments! I've addressed them.
For skewness information in HashRange, I'll tackle it with [NEMO-154](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NEMO-154)

@wonook I've sent some commits that remove /runtime/test module with minor relocation of tests.

But compiler-tests are still indivisible, because those tests are tightly coupled with multiple packages.
Please refer the dependency diagram.. It's not easy to mention all cases.
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1S5EIFBDT7INfCTwRAW3ZcxrlGxVdDuvfTnyu1LRiFQ0/edit?usp=sharing

And I prefer to place this compiler-specific tests in /compiler/test rather than /test(s).

[Nemo-152](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NEMO/issues/NEMO-152?filter=allopenissues) is for executing multiple jobs..

Then.. what this PR is for?
Could you describe the current status of multiple job support?
For example, a client can submit multiple dags, but they are ignored by driver..?
@seojangho I've resolved the conflict with the master

One more request.

Multiple jobs mean multiple _pipelines_ in Beam and multiple _actions_ in Spark, right?
If it's correct please specify it in the PR description.
Messed up while resolving conflicts. I will send a new pull request.
@sanha Thank you for you reviews! I will take your suggestions into account and add commits.

By the way, I've found out that we should've update the `AdditionalTagOutputProperty` of the sources vertex, if new vertices are inserted (for example, `SailfishPolicy` inserts a merger vertex) between the source and additional tagged output.

I've updated `SailfishPolicy` a bit, and add more tests. Can I add those commits into this PR, too?
@shpark it can be a part of this pr. Please add the commit also. I'll take a look.

I've add a new commit regarding update of `AddiitonalTagOutputProperty` of a source vertex, which is a direct parent of newly inserted vertex.

Currently, we have to manually handle this update, but in the future, we may add new methods for inserting vertices that automatically do it for us.
@shpark I agree with your opinion. I've created an [issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NEMO-162) in JIRA. Thanks for pointing out!
I'll merge once you address the comment related to the `plangenerator` package and resolve the conflicts

@seojangho @wynot12 Thanks! Can you check and comment if there are further changes that has to be made?
FYI, the PRs following this one would be: 1. actual execution of multiple DAGs in a single driver, and 2. Automatic caching (after caching is supported)
Close. Another pull request regarding the same issue will be ready soon.
Thanks for the reviews. I will reflect your corrections and suggestions into this work. Thanks!
Now additional output execution property goes to edges instead of vertices, thus we don't need to update execution property of the source vertex, after inserting vertices by reshaping passes.

Looks good to me. I've approved the PR.

Hi Arun! A warm welcome to the community.

The PR looks good to me. Moving the code to the util package also sounds good, so let me know when that's done, and I'll go ahead and merge the PR.

Please also do feel free to use the pull requests, the JIRA, and the mailing list to share **any** ideas on the project! Exciting times ahead, especially with the first release coming up soon.
I'll refile the PR using an alternative design that reuses existing task attempts, rather than introducing a separate concept of clone offsets.
@johnyangk Thanks for the review. Please check the updates.
Sounds good. I'll merge once the tests pass.

Hi @arunlakshman, sorry for my late review, I'm currently on holiday for the moment.
Refactoring the code into a util package is definitely a good direction, and changing the recursive logic to an iterative logic can make it easier for readers to perceive the code. One concern is that although it's in a good direction, it doesn't completely solve the issue. There are some missing details in the issue description (my bad), but the issue expects a more sophisticated algorithm that provides a general way to check the equality between the int predicates, instead of having to provide the range of numbers manually. Maybe we could leave the `noOfTimes` parameter as a minimum range to check (with a default value), and add a bit of a logic that checks the boundaries up to a point a particular predicate changes from true to false, or the other way around and check the equality of both predicates at that boundary.
What I've intended was to make an algorithm that works like an `equals()` method that checks the equality without requiring manual interferences.
Feel free to provide questions if there's something that's not clear!
@seojangho: thanks for adding the `formatter.xml` and `.editorconfig`
The Eclipse formatter really has lots of options! @arunlakshman Let me know if there's any room for improvement! Thanks.

@seojangho: The `formatter.xml` looks good.
I also validated the rules in `checkstyle.xml` against the rules in `formatter.xml`, and the formatter has coverd all the rules in checkstyle. Thanks.
I'll merge it after the test.
Thanks for the validation, @arunlakshman ! Also, thanks for the review, @sanha !

Hi @wonook, 
  Thanks for the detailed clarification. I still have some doubts about the method,
- Should the method check for the equality of predicates in the range [`Integer.MIN_VALUE`,`Integer.MAX_VALUE`] **OR** [`0`,`Integer.MAX_VALUE`]
- Should the method return the boolean value **OR**  the `boundary` at which the predicates starts conflicting 

Please validate my approach to find the equality of the predicates
```
for val in range[0,32]
   if isBoundary(2^val)
       break and return false
```
If no boundary was obtained in the previous stage,
```
for val in range [0,Integer.MAX_VALUE]
    if  isBboundary(val)
           break and return
```
if no boundary was obtained in both the stages then `return true`.

The performance of first stage in `O(log N)` and the second stage is `O(N)` and here `N` is the total no. of values in the test range.
This PR is now ready to be reviewed. :smile:
@sanha Thank you for the review. I've created the jira issue and updated the PR description.

@arunlakshman 
In my opinion, for our specific use case, it checks the equality of int predicates that determine the total number of iterations in a loop. In that case, I think it makes sense to start the range from the number 0 (we can make this more clear in the code).

To add a bit more of an explanation, taking a look at the `LoopVertex` implementation, a loop vertex has a `maxNumberOfIterations` variable that determines the max number of how many times to repeat the iteration, and once it gets to a point where the predicate returns true, predicate taking in the `maxNumberOfIterations` variable as its parameter, it stops the loop unrolling process. (Loop unrolling process simply appends the iteration's sub-DAG before the LoopVertex, until it reaches its termination condition - maxNumber becoming 0 or predicate returning true). Therefore, thinking only about this use case it actually makes sense to simply check the range between 0 and the `maxNumberOfIterations` variable.

Currently, we trust the developer to use this function correctly, but my point about the issue is that we could make this process to be done without the developer's interference. For instance, we could maybe receive a LoopVertex with the method to extract the `maxNumberOfIterations` variable and use it as the max value of the range to check the predicates.
Thanks @jeongyooneo! I've addressed your comments.

Thanks @arunlakshman for another great PR! The PR overall looks good to me.

Unfortunately, this time, some of the tests in /compiler/test appear to fail.
https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-nemo/builds/417679496?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification

The fastest way to reproduce test failures on the local machine (I did this myself and was able to reproduce the failures):
```
mvn clean install -T 2C -DskipTests -pl \!compiler/frontend/spark,\!examples/spark
cd compiler/optimizer/
mvn test
```

You can also run the entire test set with the following command to check that everything works ok:
```
mvn clean install -T 2C
```

Let me know if this works for you, and I'll take a quick look and merge after the tests pass. :smile:
@jeongyooneo Please resolve the conflict!

Hi @johnyangk ,

   I have made the chnages so that the unit test passes. But I am unsure about the following,

In `IRVertex.java`, if we change the line 50 from 
```super(IdManager.newVertexId());```
to
```super(that.getId());```

  Then we get the following error in the tests

```
Tests in error:
  testLoopFusionPass(edu.snu.nemo.compiler.optimizer.pass.compiletime.reshaping.LoopFusionPassTest): The DAG does not contain [destination] of the edge: [vertex-12]->[vertex-13] in [vertex-10, vertex-11, vertex-9, vertex-12, vertex-13, vertex-3, vertex-4, vertex-1, vertex-2, vertex-7, vertex-8, vertex-5, vertex-6]

Tests run: 31, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0
```

1. Do we need to copy the ID of the existing vertex while cloning (That is what stated in the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NEMO/issues/NEMO-89))
2. **OR** should we create new ID while cloning the vertex

@arunlakshman Good catch. I suppose we should create a new ID while cloning the vertex for the reasons below.

1. Each IRVertex should have a unique id within its DAG, including the clones.
2. We're using `getClone` in `LoopVertex#unRollIteration` to effectively generate clones of loops.

I'll update the JIRA issue accordingly to use new IDs for clones.

I suppose the integrity checker in `DAGBuilder` should also check for duplicate ids catch these errors. I'll file a JIRA for that as well.

@johnyangk `package-lock.json` is intended to be committed into the source repository. It provides a facility to 'time-travel' to the previous `node_modules` directory without commiting this directory itself. It's true that the file is too big, but I think it should be committed in.

Sorry for the late response. I'll run some performance tests and review the code.

TPC-H job completion times I got are (10 h1.4xlarge, Scale Factor=100):

 | My branch (master + some fixes) | My branch + This branch (merged)
-- | -- | --
Q3 | 4mins, 51sec | 5mins, 13sec
Q4 | 3mins, 22sec | 3mins, 45sec
Q5 | 7mins, 24sec | 6mins, 34sec
Q6 | 2mins, 13sec | 2mins, 21sec
Q10 | 3mins, 33sec | 3mins, 50sec
Q12 | 2mins, 55sec | 3mins, 14sec
Q13 | 3mins, 21sec | 3mins, 42sec
Q14 | 2mins, 9sec | 2mins, 21sec

This PR seems to add around 10% overhead by using the `WindowedValue` wrappers rather than raw data objects, which I think is not so bad also considering that we're still mostly faster than the Spark runner. (@seojangho - what do you think about this?)

I'll review the code now.
